You pin the resource to a specific zone (for example, VMs, managed disks, IP addresses)
The platform replicates automatically across zones (for example, zone-redundant storage, SQL Database).
Services are always available from Azure geographies and are resilient to zone-wide outages as well as region-wide outages.

Most Azure regions are paired with another within the same geography at least 300 miles (480km) away to enable replication and reduce the impact of large scale outages (eg. natural disasters). This is not always automatic and should be configured by the customer.

• Replication and therefore resiliency to large scale outages
  • In event of large outage, one region is prioritised for quickest restore
  • Planned Azure updates are rolled out to one of these one at a time to minimise downtime and outage.
  • Data stays within its geography for tax and law-enforcement, jurisdiction purposes.

prompt: Is it possible to have multiple subscriptions in one account? Why would you need it?
answer: Yes, although you only require one, multiple enable the configuration of different billing models and access management policies.

answer:

  • To reflect organisational structures: limiting some departments but not others
  • To easily track costs across needs (production, testing, development)
